loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en: Zubaida, a 30-year-old married woman, runs a small boutique at home to provide for her family. She purchases cloth from the market at low prices, sews items of clothing and then sells them to the people in her community. She always has a great product selection to offer, and she earns a good income that contributes to her family's well-being. For the improvement of her business, Zubaida has requested a loan of 40,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR) to buy a greater variety of cloth and spools of thread in various colors. These will allow her to fulfill the demands of her customers on time. With a good credit history, this will be Zubaida's fifth loan.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety of cloth and thread

loans.name: Alberto

texts.pt:
Alberto é comerciante por conta própria, casado pai de dois filhos que estão a estudar ainda no nίvel primário além dos filhos não sustenta mais ninguém, vive na casa própria.
Diz que com o valor do credito quer comprar material de construcao da sua casa tais como: barrotes, ferro, cimento e blocos.
Tem como plano para o futuro construção do murro de vedação do seu quintal, um estabelicimeto comercial na sua casa onde a sua esposa podera  vender produtos basicos para sustentar  outras necessidades da familia.
Tem como grande desafio terminar com a construçãao da sua casa, efectuar os pagamentos nas datas estabelecidas no contrato
texts.en:
Alberto is a self-employed trader who is married and has two children who are still in primary school. Aside from his children, he doesn't support anyone else and lives in a house he owns.

He says that with this loan he wants to buy construction materials for his house such as: beams, iron, cement and blocks.

He has plans for building a wall around his yard and a commercial establishment at his home where his wife can sell basic products to support his family's other needs.

His biggest challenge is to finish the construction work on his house and to make his loan repayments on the dates established by his contract with Hluvuku.

loans.use: buy construction materials for his house such as: beams, iron, cement and blocks.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is 44 years old and lives in the town of Tororo in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, all of whom are now in school. For the past 22 years, Joseph has been working hard to manage his business, which sells produce. To help expand his business, Joseph has applied for a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more produce, and it will help Joseph to generate greater profits and to educate his children. Joseph hopes that in the future he will be able to grow the business. Joseph is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joseph who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more produce to sell.

loans.name: Kaneez

texts.en: Kaneez is a 42-year-old married woman. She has been helping in her husband's business of furniture making. Over time they have become famous for providing good quality furniture. She is a responsible mother of four children and provides them with the basic necessities of life. In order to buy good quality wood, together with packs of polish and nails in larger quantity, she applied for a loan of 40,000 Pakistan Rupees (PKR) from Kashf Foundation. In this way, she will be able to cater to more customers without delays, which will ultimately help in bringing home more cash. Kaneez dreams of providing a bright and prosperous future to her children.

loans.use: to buy good quality wood, packs of polish and nails in larger quantity.

loans.name: Intisar

texts.en: Intisar is a 56-year-old widowed Palestinian refugee, who has been working hard for her living since her husband passed away, leaving her alone with no one to help her with her living expenses. Seven years ago, Intisar started her own business selling veils, which attracted most of the camp’s population who want such items, even through her limited income and living costs have made it impossible to develop her business widely and properly. For this reason, Intisar is taking out a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to increase her merchandise with a specially released summer collection that will attract’ customers’ attention and develop her business. This will be Intisar's sixth loan cycle at Al Majmoua. Through her previous loans, she was capable of increasing her business capital, since she couldn't save enough money from her limited income for this purpose. She hopes that one day she can open another business that will cover most of her living needs.

loans.use: to increase her stock of merchandise with a specially released summer collection that will attract customer attention.

loans.name: Ananias

texts.pt:
O senhor Ananias é casado pai de 10 filhos dos quais apenas 3 estudam os restantes 7 já são maiores de idade, vive na casa própria e  trabalha como chefe do sector de administração e finançase nas horas livres faz machamba.
Com o valor do empréstimo irá comprar 2 janelas,  1 porta, sacos de cimento para dar continuidade a sua obra e pagar mão de obra.
No futuro gostaria de adiquirir uma viatura para uso pessoal e facilitar o transporte de produtos da sua machamba.
Diz que ira pagar conforme o acordado no contrato e que ira solicitar mais creditos para puder concretizar seus sonhos.
texts.en:
Mr. Ananias is married and the father of 10 children, only 3 of whom go to school as the other 7 are already of age. He lives in a house he owns and works as a department head in finance and administration. In his spare time he farms a small piece of land.

With the value of this loan he will buy 2 windows, 1 door and sacks of cement to continue with the building of his house and to pay for labour.

In future he'd like to buy a vehicle for personal use and to facilitate the transport of products from his farmland.

He says he will pay back the loan as agreed in the contract and that he will be asking for further loans to make his dreams come true.

loans.use: 2 windows, 1 door and sacks of cement to continue with the building of his house and to pay for labour.

loans.name: Marium

texts.en: Marium is a 49-year-old married woman who has been doing business selling milk for many years. She has five buffaloes, two cows and four goats in milk. She sells milk to many of her neighbors and other people in her community. Her business is good enough for her to lead a decent life. She also sells animals to generate extra income. She has three children. She is highly motivated to provide them a beautiful life, one with food and clothing. She has improved her business to meet the day-to-day expenses of life. This is her fourth year with Kashf Foundation; she is happily running her business with its support. Now she has applied for a loan of PKR 40,000 to buy one additional cow and feed for her cattle. She hopes to increase her milk production capacity, which will ultimately help in generating more cash.

loans.use: to buy one additional cow and feed for her milk cattle.

loans.name: Sheema

texts.en: Sheema, age 39, is a married woman. Her business is raising and selling animals. She buys baby goats and calves at low prices, brings them up, and then sells them in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family’s income. At present she has four goats. She needs to improve her business to cover her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 45,000 to buy more animals. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income level. She is in her sixth loan cycle and has a good credit history.

loans.use: to buy more baby goats and calves to raise and sell.

loans.name: Saleem

texts.en: Saleem is a 51-year-old married woman and a mother of eight children. The income generated by her husband is insufficient to cover all household expenses, so she initiated her business selling milk. She has two buffaloes for milk.  She has been doing this for many years and has become famous for providing good quality milk in her locality. With the support of Kashf Foundation, she has gradually improved her business.  Currently, she requested a loan of PKR 55,000 to purchase another buffalo. This will help her to increase her sales which will ultimately help in generating more income for her. She is in her seventh loan cycle with good credit history.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 39 years old and lives in the town of Kacwamba in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children; neither of them are currently in school. For the past five years, Margret has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells grocery items. 

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more grocery items, and will help Margret to generate greater profits and stock up the shop. 

Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business. 

Margret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of fruit and cereals

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Sharif is 40-years-old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past four years, Sharif has been working hard to manage his clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Sharif has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes and will help Sharif to generate greater profits and expand the business. Sharif hopes that in the future he will be able to have a bigger business. 

Sharif is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sharif who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes

loans.name: Shadi

texts.en:
Shadi is a 28-year-old married man from Rafah city. He is a father of three kids, a son and two daughters.  He works as an employee in the public sector where he earns a low income.  His income is not enough to cover all the family's needs.

Shadi would like to improve the family's living conditions so he decided to work in transferring goods using a rickshaw.  Shadi took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new rickshaw for his business.  By taking this loan, Shadi will be able to work extra hours transferring goods to the local market. This will increase his income.

Shadi appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new rickshaw for his business.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a married man; he has four children. He describes himself to be determined. 

He operates a market stall where he sells bread. He has been involved in this business for four years. His primary customers are individuals and schools. He describes his biggest business challenge to be financial challenges. 

He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase additional stock. 

This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His business goal is to own his own depot outlets within five years.   

He will use some of the anticipated profits from the loan to educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of bread.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a married man. He describes himself to be focused and disciplined. He operates a retail business where he sells beds, chairs, and other items. He has been involved in this business for four years. He describes his biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. 

He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of beds, chairs, and other items for sell. 

This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of beds, chairs and other items to sell

loans.name: Elmir

texts.en:
Elmir is a 34-year-old man. He has lovely family, a wife and two daughters. His wife is a housewife and helps Elmir in his business. Their elder daughter goes to seventh grade, and the little daughter is going to fifth grade. The family members are IDP (Internally displaced Persons) from Fuzuli city and now live in the Fuzuli region. 

Elmir has been in the animal breeding business. He buys little calves, raises them, and sells in the bazaar to earn money. Summer is coming and he wants to vaccinate his animals. 

Therefore, he has requested a loan in the amount of 1,000 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). 

Elmir is thankful to Kiva and lenders for this help. 

In the future, he wants to start to produce dairy products and sell them.

loans.use: to pay for vaccination of his animals

loans.name: Ebisiba

texts.en:
Ebisiba is a married woman. She has four children, with ages ranging from 2 to 10 years. She describes herself to be good. 

She operates a retail business where she sells cabbages; she has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of cabbages. 

Her business goal is to expand within five years. 

She hopes that in the future she will expand.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cabbages

loans.name: Robina

texts.en: Robina is a 44 year old active lady who has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason she requested a loan of 40,000 PKR from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan to buy more spools of threads in different colors, packs of laces, zippers and buttons.  She hopes to create a means of increasing revenues so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. She is in her 7th loan cycle and thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors, packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Marium

texts.en:
Marium is a 48-year-old married woman. She has six children. Her husband (also shown in the photo) has been running a butcher shop for the past six years. He sells meat and chicken to many of his community members. He has become famous for providing healthy meat and chicken. 

For the improvement of her husband’s business, Marium has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR. With this loan amount he will be able to purchase more animals to meet market demands consistently. 

Marium aspires to save money for their better future.

loans.use: to purchase more animals.

loans.name: Akwadu Group

texts.en:
Gladys has been selling ladies’ tops and skirts for five years. She realized that women demand more and more for their personal appearance, and therefore decided to sell ladies’ wear. Gladys sells at the market. 

In the future, she would like to have her own large space with employees to manage other joints that will open. 

She will invest the loan she has received to buy ladies’ tops and skirts to sell to customers.

Gladys and the other three members together are requesting GHS 1,600 to increase their stock.

loans.use: to buy ladies' tops and skirts to sell to customers.

loans.name: Callen

texts.en:
Callen is a married woman. She has three children with ages ranging from 4 to 9 years. She describes herself to be determined. 

She operates a retail store where she sells rice, sugar and other food items. She has been involved in this business for five years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of financial resources. 

Her business goal is to own a large wholesale shop within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase additional stock for her store.  

She will use the anticipated profits from the loan to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her store

loans.name: Mirbagir

texts.en: Mirbagir was born in 1979. He is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) and now lives in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has two sons, who are in fourth and fifth class of school. Mirbagir has been in the retail business for 10 years, and wants to borrow his second loan to improve his business. He needs a loan of 700 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat) to repair the exterior of his store. It should be noted that he successfully repaid his first loan. Mirbagir says “dear Kiva organization I’m thankful to you for your help”

loans.use: to repair the exterior of his store

loans.name: Rizwana

texts.en: Rizwana is a 38-year-old hard working, married woman. When she got married, she felt that she should support her husband to improve their financial condition, so she started a business of selling cloth. In time she has become famous among her neighbors for her collections. Currently she needs a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase  bundles of good quality cloth in different colors. She is in her 6th loan cycle with good credit history. She hopes to earn substantial profits through this investment. This would lead her to live a decent life and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of good quality cloth in different colors.

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à MEDINE l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des condiments, des habits et des poissons. Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME sont à leur  4ème  prêt solidaire. FANTA 2ème  femme debout de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 20 chemises, 20 robes, 20 pantalons et 10 foulards. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 16 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme Group are, on average, 35 years old and have four children.  They live in traditional, extended families in the neighbourhood of Medine in San, Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family ties.  They buy and sell food ingredients, clothing and fish.

This will be the fourth group loan for the Djiguisseme Group, the previous loans were all fully and correctly repaid.

Fanta (standing second from the right in the photo) plans to use her loan to buy 20 shirts, 20 dresses, 20 pairs of trousers and 10 scarves from local wholesalers.  She sells her clothing to both men and women on a cash or credit basis.

Fanta expects to make an average monthly profit of 16,000 francs CFA, which will be used to pay for healthcare and school costs, buy food and clothing, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
This is 50 year-old Marie. She is widowed, and has four children ages 22, 17, 14 and 11. 

In 2004, Marie established her canned tomatoes, soap, rice, flour, vegetable oil, onion, caustic soda, magi, and sugar business. She began her business because she dropped out of school due to the traditional belief that a girl child should not be educated.  She joined her mother in doing her business, and later got married.  

She started taking rice by bags from the Lebanese shops on a credit basis.  The profit she generated was used to start her own business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 988,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Marie requires a loan in order to purchase the following items: bags of different kinds of rice, bags of flour, sugar, cornmeal, containers of vegetable oil, packets of maggi, salt, cartoons of canned tomatoes, etc.  

In the future, Marie plans to invest in the business and expand more to purchase a piece of land.  The loan will help to maximize more profit as additional income. 

She graduated from group lending to the individual loan, and hopes to pay within the stipulated dates.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Samar

texts.en:
Samar is a 31-year-old mother of two. She has been running her accessories, bags, perfumes and cosmetics selling shop for two and a half years. She and her husband's combined incomes aren't enough to cover her family's increasing needs. That is why she is working hard to expand her business and diversify her products so that she'll be able to increase her expected income.

Samar is acquiring her first loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to pay the expenses of moving her shop to a wider place and increasing her business merchandise with a special released collection. Through this loan she'll move to a wider shop where she can display and diversify her merchandise in an attractive way which will increase her selling and develop her family's living.

She hopes that, through the increased income, she might change her children from public school to a better private one.

loans.use: to pay the expenses of moving her shop to a wider place and increasing her business merchandise with a special released collection.

loans.name: Kankeletiki Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe KANKELETIKI ont en moyenne 36 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à MEDINE l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des condiments, des habits, des poissons et des produits divers. Les femmes du groupe KANKELETIKI sont à leur  1er  prêt solidaire. TATA 1ère  femme debout de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 20Mètres de tissus léger et 1 demi rouleau de Bazin. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Kankeletiki Group are, on average, 36 years old and have four children.  They live in traditional, extended families in the neighbourhood of Medine, in San, Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family connections.  They buy and sell food ingredients, clothing, fish and various other products.

This will be the first loan for the Kankeletiki Group.

Tata (standing on the left in the photo) plans to use her loan to buy 20 metres of light fabric and half a roll of damask fabric, from local wholesalers.  Her customers are both men and women, and they pay cash or buy on credit.

Tata expects to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA which will be used to pay for healthcare and school costs, buy food and clothing, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Sikikadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe SIKIKADI ont en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à MEDINE l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des condiments, des habits, des ustensiles et des produits divers. Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe SIKIKADI sont à leur  2ème  prêt solidaire. CHATA 2ème  femme de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 10Kgs d’oignon, 15Kgs de Sel, 2 boîtes de tomate concentré, 1 demi paquet de  Cube Maggi et 10Litres d’huile. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Sikikadi Group are, on average, 37 years old and have four children.  They live in traditional, extended families in the Medine district of San, in Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family connections.  They buy and sell food ingredients, clothing, kitchen utensils and various other products.

This will be the second group loan for the women, the previous loan was fully and correctly repaid.

Chata (standing second from the right in the photo) plans to use her loan to buy 10kg of onions, 15kg of salt, 2 tins of concentrated tomatoes, half a packet of Maggi stock cubes and 10 litres of oil, locally.  She sells her products to both men and women, for cash or on credit.

Chata expects to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA, which will be used to pay healthcare and school costs, buy food and clothing, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients for resale.

loans.name: Yoselin Marisol

texts.es: Yoselin tiene 20 años de edad y habita junto a su familia. Ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas desde hace 5 años. Es una joven muy trabajadora y responsable. Yoselin solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la reparación del techo de la vivienda dado que se encuentra deteriorado. Con el monto solicitado comprará lámina galvanizada, madera y clavos.
texts.en: Yoselin is 20 years old and she lives with her family. She has worked making and selling tortillas for 5 years. She is a very hardworking and responsible young woman. Yoselin is asking FUSAI for this loan to invest in repairing the roof on her home because it has deteriorated. With the amount she has asked for, she will buy galvanized sheeting, wood and nails.

loans.use: to buy galvanized sheeting, wood and nails to repair the roof on her home.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 59 years old, married to Sarah, and they have five children between the ages of 1 and 13.  He has been in the farming business for the last five years, with a monthly income of KES.15,000                           

He has applied for his second loan of KES. 50,000 with VisionFund Kenya, to buy farm inputs (e.g. seedlings and fertilizer) for use on the farm to improve the harvest. 

He plans to use the anticipated income to expand his business and educate his children.
	
Daniel hopes to have a bright future and venture in large-scale farming

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, e.g. pesticides and seedlings

loans.name: Fuente De Trabajo Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario lo integran cuatro socias y lo coordina la señora Arsenia, mujer exitosa en su vida laboral de 30 años de edad y soltera se dedica a la comercializar ropa nueva a los pobladores de su comunidad, el negocio lo impulsó hace dos años cuando sus hermanas le hicieron un préstamos para que ella se desarrollara, desde ese tiempo a la actualidad su clientela ha aumentado  y por ende su demanda de ropa lo que la ha motivado a prestar en esta institución para invertir en mercadería como blusas, talladores, pantalón para damas, pantalón para caballeros, bóxer, blúmer, taloneras, etc. Los otros socios son las señoras Flor de 44 años de edad propietaria de una pulpería, Lilliam de 57 años de edad comerciante de ropa nueva y de segunda a los pobladores de su comunidad, y Ana de 20 años de edad quien ofrece ropa nueva de manera ambulante a los pobladores de su comunidad. Estas socias solicitan el crédito por primera vez para aumentar sus mercaderías y por ende sus ganancias.
texts.en:
The solidarity group has four members and is coordinated by Mrs. Arsenia. She has a successful career, is 30 years old, single, and markets new clothes to the people of her community. The business started two years ago when her sisters gave her some loans so she could develop. From that time until now, her clientele has increased and as a result her clothing demand. What has motivated her to borrow with this institution is to be able to invest in merchandise such as blouses, carvers, ladies´ pants, men´s pants, boxers, knickers, skirts, etc.

The other members are 44-year-old Flor, owner of the local grocery store, 57-year-old Lilliam, who sells new and used clothing to the people of her community, and 20-year-old Ana, who sells clothing as a street vendor to the people of her community. These members are asking for the loan for the first time to increase their merchandise and therefore their earnings.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as pants, shirts, blouses, carvers, etc.

loans.name: Margarita De Los Ángeles

texts.es: La señora Margarita es una mujer laboriosa, de 19 años de edad, acompañada y madre de un hijo quien es su mayor motivación para su superación, es propietaria de un taller de zapatería por más de un año, el negocio lo impulsó con ayuda de su compañero de vida, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de materia prima como es cuero sintético, pega blanca, pega amarilla, suelas, hebillas, hilos, etc., con esta inversión la socia podrá satisfacer parte de la demanda que tiene aumentando así las ganancias lo que le permitirá mejorar su nivel de vida para ofrecerle a su niño mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en: Margarita is a hard working woman. She is 19 years old, married, and the mother of a son who is her main motivation  to get ahead. She has been the owner of a cobbler shop for  more than a year.  She was driven to start the business with the help of her life's companion. She is asking for the loan to buy raw materials such as synthetic leather, white glue, yellow glue, soles, buckles, thread, etc. With this investment, she will be able to satisfy a part of the demand that is increasing. The profits will allow her to improve her quality of life to offer her son better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy materials such as white glue, yellow glue, synthetic leather, soles, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her clothing sales business.

loans.name: Vegaspamba (Gualaceo) Group

texts.es:
El grupo de crédito Vegaspamba está formado por 10 mujeres que viven en la parroquia Jadan de Gualaceo, su clima es frio, una de sus bebidas típicas  es la chicha de jora que se comparte durante las fiestas, aún se acostumbra la vestimenta de lana que consiste de sombrero, chalina, pantalón o polleras, su gente es amable y cordial que se esfuerzan para salir adelante y sacar adelante a sus familias.
Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señora Mariela, tiene 27 años de edad, es casada y fruto de su unión conyugal ha concebido una hija de 8 años de edad, su esposo labora como albañil, la casa en la que viven es propia.
Doña Mariela es una socia trabajadora que se dedica a cuidar de su hogar y a la agricultura, lo que cultiva es para el consumo de su hogar, también se dedica a la cría de cuyes y trabaja como jornalera cuidando un invernadero de tomates de lunes a viernes, en su tiempo libre o por las noches fabrica sogas para la venta, esta actividad aprendió de sus padres. El dinero de su crédito es para la compra de cabuya para la elaboración de sogas. Su meta es salir adelante.
texts.en:
The Vegaspamba credit group is made up of 10 women who live in the Jadan de Gualaceo parish. It has a cool climate and one of its traditional drinks is chicha de jora, which they share during festivals. They still use the traditional clothing, which consists of a hat, shawl, and pants or a skirt. The people are friendly and cordial and they strive to get ahead and to get their families ahead.
 
One of the members of this group is Mariela. She is 27, married and from her marriage has an eight year old daughter. Her husband works as a bricklayer and they own the house they live in. Mariela is a hardworking member who takes care of her home and also farms. What she grows is for household consumption, and she also raises guinea pigs and works as a laborer in a tomato greenhouse Monday through Friday. In her free time, or in the evening, she makes rope to sell. She learned this activity from her parents. The money from the loan is to buy cabuya to make the rope. Her goal is to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy cabuya.

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en: Monicah is a married woman. She has 1 child. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail business where she makes and repairs clothes and also sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a competitive location and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials and charcoal. Her business goal is to own a big shop within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials and charcoal.

loans.name: Daglus

texts.en: Daglus is a married man. He has 3 children with ages ranging from 7 years to 11 years. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a M-Pesa outlet. He has been involved in this business for 4 years. He describes his biggest business challenge to be a lack of financial resources. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to improve cashflow. His business goal is to own many M-Pesa outlets within 5 years. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. He will use the anticipated profits from the loan to educate his children.

loans.use: to improve cashflow for his M-Pesa business.

loans.name: Erick

texts.en: Erick is a married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself to be committed. He operates a retail business where he makes metallic windows, chairs and other items to sell. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located in an area fit for the business and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of welding materials. His business goal is to be successful within 5 years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of welding materials.

loans.name: Hanh's Group

texts.en: Hanh is 58 years old and lives with her children. For the past 7 years, Hanh has been selling soft drinks from the front of her house to earn an income to support her family. Hanh is the group leader of a 8-member loan group that lives in Ho Chi Minh City. In the picture, she is in the first from right wearing a pink T-shirt. Each of the other group members are requesting loans to fund income-generating activities. Hanh is requesting a loan to purchase a greater quantity and variety of beverages to sell from in front of her house. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional ones. She also hopes that through her loan she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Lac

texts.en:
Lac is 40 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a farmer. She has been running a food stall in front of her door for 3 years. She started this business to cover her expenses and raise her children. They live in Ho Chi Minh City.

Lac is requesting a loan to purchase new furniture to better accommodate her customers and attract new customers. 

She hopes that through the loan she will be able to expand her business activities and have money to reinvest in her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase new furniture for her food stall.

loans.name: Caren

texts.en: Caren is a 33-year-old married woman. She has 3 children with ages ranging from 2 years to 10 years. She describes herself to be hardworking and determined. She operates a farming business where she sells maize and beans. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a rural area and her primary customers are local citizens. She describes her biggest business challenge to be poor weather. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to diversify the business. She hopes that, in the future, she will be financially independent. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to diversify her farming business.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a 28-year-old married woman. She has 2 children with ages ranging from 5 years to 10 years. She describes herself to be industrious. She operates a farming business where she sells bananas. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her primary customers are local citizens. She describes her biggest business challenges to be drought and famine. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase farming inputs. Her business goal is to expand the farm and improve her standard of living within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, she will be an independent farmer. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase farming inputs.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a married woman. She has seven children; she describes herself to be honest. 

She operates a restaurant where she cooks food to sell. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a busy and convenient place, and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of sufficient funds. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food to sell. 

Her business goal is to expand within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a 30-year-old married woman. She has two children, ages 3 and 10. She describes herself to be industrious. 

She operates a farming business where she sells maize. She has been involved in this business for ten years. Her business is located in a rural area and her primary customers are local citizens. She describes her biggest business challenge to be poor weather. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase farming inputs. 

Her business goal is to own a cereal store within five years. 

She hopes that in the future she will be financially independent. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase farming inputs

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman and she has 5 children. She describes herself to be honest.

She operates a retail business where she sells curtains and clothes. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a busy and convenient place, and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of sufficient funds.

She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more stock of curtains and clothes to sell. Her business goal is to expand within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP microfinance bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of curtains and clothes to sell

loans.name: Vuong

texts.en:
Vuong, 49, lives in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City with her family, which includes three children and her husband. Her husband earns money as a vehicle parking attendant. She supports her family by making many kinds of handcrafts such as lanterns. She stared this business eight years ago. 

Vuong would  like to get a loan to buy materials to increase her production of handcrafted lanterns. She also hopes her business will ensure that her family members, and especially her children, will have a better education and a better future.

loans.use: to buy materials for making handcrafted lanterns.

loans.name: Hon

texts.en:
Hon, 47, lives in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City with his family, including three children and his wife. His wife stays at home taking care of the family. He supports his family by pressing and packaging plastic food bags. He stared this business seven years ago. 

Hon would like to get a loan to buy a plastic bag pressing and packaging machine in order to increase his production and income. 

He hopes his business will ensure that his family members, and especially his children, will have a better education and a better future.

loans.use: To buy a plastic bag pressing and packaging machine.

loans.name: Vinh

texts.en:
Vinh, 49, lives in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City with his family, including a son and his wife. He and his wife earn an income running a general store in front of their house. 

He started this business 12 years ago. He sells sugar, toys for kids, soft drinks, yogurt and other household items to people in his community. 

He is requesting a loan to expand his business by buying a greater variety of products such as food and beverages to sell at his store.

He hopes his business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist him in improving his family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy food and beverages for selling at his store.

loans.name: Hong's Group

texts.en:
Hong is 53 years old and lives in Ho Chi Minh City. For the past 10 years, Hong has been running a food stall to sell pork and noodle soup in front of her house. She is the group leader of a 4-member group that lives in Ho Chi Minh City. In the picture, she is the third from the left wearing a red and black blouse.

Each of the other group members are requesting loans to fund income-generating activities. Hong is requesting a loan to purchase better quality noodles and pork to make soup for selling at her food stall. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional ones. She also hopes that through her loan she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to buy noodles and pork to make pork and noodle soup to sell at her food stall

loans.name: Nam

texts.en:
Nam is requesting a new loan to buy a range of food products to restock his general store. This purchase will help him to better meet the needs of his customers. His previous loan enabled him to improve him business and offer his customers a greater variety of products.

He hopes that his new loan will assist him in increasing the size of his store and increase sales, and will also help him to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity of food products to stock his store

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong is requesting a new loan to buy a sewing machine and pay school fees for her child. Phuong's previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income to support her family.

She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase her sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and pay school fees for her child

loans.name: Agni Gangamaa Group

texts.en:
Dhanamani is the leader of a group and lives in Muniguda of Rayagada district of Odisha, India. She is a married woman of 40 years. She has a small family comprised of three members, herself, her husband and one son aged 21. The member seating third from left with raised hand is Dhanamani. 

Like most families in the village she has been managing a small fruit business in her village. Her husband helps her in the business by going to different markets at nearby villages. She has already accessed four loans and this is her fifth  loan cycle. 

At the time of accessing the first loan her husband  used to go to weekly markets in nearby villages for selling vegetables. Out of their small income they are maintaining their family in a low profile. To improve her living conditions and to earn some extra income Dhanamani accessed loans one after the other for four times. At present her monthly income is about Rs.7,500 from her fruit business, which is not sufficient to lead a better life. So, she wants to take a further loan to purchase fruits and vegetables in large quantity for wholesaling.  She has a cherished dream to have a permanent stall in front of her house.

The other five members of the group are also doing the same business.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables in large quantity for wholesaling

loans.name: Tirupati Swamy Group

texts.en:
Jasobanti, aged about 49 years, is the group leader of a six-member group in Muniguda town situated in Rayagada district of Odisha state in India. Her family comprises three members, herself, her husband, and one daughter aged 19. The member standing third from left with raised hand is Jasobanti. At present she is running a fancy shop in her locality. She is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts.

During 2008 she, along with other members of her village, formed a group and for the first time they took a loan from Mahashakti Foundation for the development of their existing business. Jasobanti’s husband is assisting her to run the business smoothly. At present her family income is about Rs.6,500  per month which is not sufficient to maintain the family. 

To improve her living conditions and to earn some extra income she wants to access another loan.  From the loan amount she will purchase beauty creams, nail polish, deodorant, ladies' items and gift materials to improve her business.

The other five members are doing a fish business, a leaf plate business, a hotel, and a fancy shop.

loans.use: to purchase beauty creams, nail polish, deodorant, ladies' items and gift materials

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is a married woman. She has 3 children. She describes herself to be optimistic.

She operates a food stall where she sells fish. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be stock shortages.

She will use the 20,000 KES loan to purchase additional stock. Her business goal is to own her own restaurant within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.  She will use the anticipated profits from the loan to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a 38-year-old married man. He has four children. He describes himself to be focused. He operates a farming business where he sells tea. He has been involved in this business for eight years. His business is located in a rural area, and his primary customers are local citizens. He describes his biggest business challenge to be poor roads. 

He will use the 20,000 Kenyan shillings loan to expand the business. He will use the anticipated profits from the loan to build a house for himself and his family.

loans.use: to expand his farming business

loans.name: Joumana

texts.en:
Joumana is a 45-year-old mother of six. She and her husband work hard to provide them with the necessary things for living and education.

Joumana has sold Tupperware for 11 years from her house, and she is working hard to keep on developing her business and increasing its capital to provide her family with a better income.

Today, Joumana is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to pay for her son's increasing college tuition fees, in addition to investing part of the loan in buying newly released merchandise with special summer designs.

She is working hard to open her own retail shop so she can diversify her products and increase her selling. This will improve and develop her family's living.

loans.use: To pay for her son's increasing college tuition fees.

loans.name: Dolrose

texts.en:
Dolrose is a 35-year-old married woman. She has one child. She describes herself as optimistic. 

She operates a tailoring service. She has been involved in this business for four years. She describes her biggest business challenge as a lack of capital. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase additional materials. Her business goal is to own three electric sewing machines within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from 3 years to 9 years. She describes herself as determined. 

She operates a depot where she sells bread. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her primary customers are individuals, shops and schools. She describes her biggest business challenge as a lack of financial resources. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to open a second depot. Her business goal is to own many depots within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits from this loan to educate her children.

loans.use: to open a second depot.

loans.name: Abdulrahman

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Abdulrahman. He is single and has no children. 

In 2010, Abdulrahman established his Tele-Center & Barbing (Barber) Shop business. He began his business because he wants to generate income to further his education. His business is located on the outskirts of the city and his main customers are general community people. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, he earns about SLL 500,000 every month from this business. 

Abdulrahman would like a loan in the amount of SLL 4 ,500,000. He requires a loan in order to buy a clipper machine, movie chargers, and CD plates for resale. 

In the future, Abdulrahman plans to open another, bigger shop that will accommodate more customers and to also further his education up to university Level. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy a clipper machine, movie chargers, and CD plates for resale.

loans.name: Hoang

texts.en: Hoang would like to take a further loan to buy food for her food stall and pay school fees for her children. Her previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in further expanding the size of her business, attracting new customers and increasing sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy food to sell from her stall and pay school fees

loans.name: Laxmi Sriya Group

texts.en:
Swapna, 34 years of age, is the leader of a group that hails from Muniguda village of Rayagada district of Odisha, India. She lives with her husband. The member sitting second from left with raised hand is Swapna.

Swapna is is running a seasonal goods shop in her locality.  Her husband also helps her to improve the sales of their business. During 2010 Swapna, along with other members of her locality, formed a group and took a loan from Mahashakti Foundation for development of their existing business. This is her fourth cycle loan.  

At the time of accessing her first loan, her sales were not sufficient to meet her daily needs. Out of their small income they are maintaining their family in a low profile. Now she is very confident in running her business and has developed her business significantly. At present her monthly income is about Rs.7,000. She wants to access a further loan to purchase bulk quantity of seasonal items like pulses, turmeric, hill brooms etc.  She has a strong desire to establish a grocery shop in the nearby market.

The other five members of her groupsare doing a milk business, a seasonal business, a medicine store and a hotel.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal items like pulses (lentils), turmeric, and hill brooms

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 34 years old and the first born in a family of five. He lives in a small town called Luanshya, located in the Copperbelt Province of Zambia. He operates a Zoona mobile money transfer business. 

Stephen has a high school diploma, which he attained in the year 2000. He did not attend college and ventured into running small businesses in order to cover his young brothers and sisters’ school fees. In the last 14 years, Stephen says he has run several small businesses like selling airtime credit. His current mobile money business has a more reliable stream of income, which brings more stability for Stephen. 

Stephen’s current challenge in growing his business is accessing working capital. He explains that his business has not expanded much and the reason for this is that he does not have the necessary capital to invest in his business in order to offer his services to more customers.  This loan will allow Stephen to have more cash available in his business to serve additional customers and earn more commission. He will also use the money from this loan to pay off his existing trading booth where he operates his business.  Stephen is hopeful that once he starts making this additional profit, he can open another outlet and begin to expand to other locations.

Stephen is grateful for the opportunity to be connected with Kiva lenders. He says this loan is the beginning of great things for his family and business.

loans.use: To pay for his trading booth and increase the money that he uses to serve customers daily

loans.name: Bet Al- Na'ama Group

texts.en:
This group is called Bet Al- Na'ama. It is comprised of four women from Sana'a, Yemen. They are requesting a loan of 140,000 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB.

Ahlam is the leader of the group. She is a 25-year-old married woman with only one daughter. She lives with her small family in their own house in Sana'a. Ahlam works as a housewife, and she is a very dynamic woman. Her husband is an employee in the army. Over time he could accumulate a good amount of money and bought a piece of land. That land cost him a lot of money. Ahlam supported him with a lot of her own money. 

Now, Ahlam and her husband want to build their own house on that land. Unfortunately, they don't have enough money to do that. For this reason, Ahlam applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase construction materials such as cement and bricks in order to build their own house on the land they purchased. 

Ahlam hopes to build her house and renovate it. She hopes to build more than one floor and renovate them.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials such as cement and bricks in order to build a house on purchased land.

loans.name: Minh

texts.en: Minh, 64, is widowed and has two children. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. Minh started a food stall 12 years ago. She sells fried rice cakes for people in her community. She is requesting a loan to help her raise the money that she needs to buy a small house. She hopes that through the loan, she will be able to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a small house

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a female Kiva borrower. She has four children with ages ranging from 9 years to 15 years. She describes herself as optimistic. 

She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in an urban area. She describes her biggest business challenge as a lack of financial resources. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase additional stock. Her business goal is to establish a wholesale business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have better cash flow and an improved standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a married man. He describes himself to be optimistic. He operates a retail business where he sells charcoal. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located in an urban area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be a lack of funds. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase additional stock. He hopes that in the future, his business will have frequent cashflow and provide a better standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en:
Phoebe is a 30-year-old married woman. She has two children, 3 years old and 9 years old. She describes herself as determined. 

She operates a shop where she sells flour and cooking fat and other household goods. She has been involved in this business for five years. She describes her biggest business challenge as theft. 

She will use the KES 15,000 loan to purchase additional stock. Her business goal is to own a wholesale store within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will own a supermarket. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Pecilah

texts.en: Pecilah is a 20-year-old married woman. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a M-Pesa outlet where she provides M-Pesa services (money transfer service) and sells other products. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of capital. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase additional stock. Her business goal is to own a supermarket within 5 years.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a married man. He has one child. He describes himself to be capable and determined. He operates a market stall where he sells potatoes, cabbages, carrots and other vegetables. He has been involved in this business for three years. He describes his biggest business challenge to be a lack of sufficient capital. 

He will use the 20,000 Kenyan shillings loan to expand and improve the business. He hopes that in the future, his business will be prosperous. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. He will use the anticipated profits from the loan to improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to improve and expand his market business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman. She describes herself to be risk taker.

She operates a retail business where she sells fruits, vegetables and other items. She has been involved in this business for 7 years. Her business is located in a viable location. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds.

She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more stock of fruits, vegetables and other items she sells. Her business goal is to have a bigger shop within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will be successful. This is her first loan with SMEP microfinance bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fruits, vegetables and other items she sells

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself as being trustworthy. 

Ann operates a retail store where she sells household goods. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of sufficient working capital. 

Ann will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase additional stocks. Her business goal is to expand the business and improve her standard of living within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of household goods to sell.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 36 years old and married. He and his wife have six children between 11 years and 7 months old. 

He has been in the farming business for the last 16 years with a monthly income of KES 20,000                           

He has applied for his sixth loan of KES 50,000 with Vision fund Kenya to buy farm inputs such as seedlings and fertilizer for use in the farm to improve the harvest. He repaid his previous loan successfully. 

He plans to use the anticipated income to expand his business and educate his children. He hopes to have a bright future and venture into large-scale farming.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more women's clothes and resell them to customers.

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.es: Jose esta agradecido con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda que le han brindado el podrá realizar mejoras en la vivienda donde habita como arreglo de paredes, pintado, arreglo de ventanas, entre otros; asi podrá mejorar su calidad de vida; sobre todo porque es un joven con muchas ganas de salira delnate y para ello traaja como personal de limpieza y de mantenimiento de maquinas en una pequeña empresa de su ciudad con lo cual puede tener ingresos para solventar los gastos de su hogar y luchar por hacer realidad su gran sueño:” Tener su casa propia”.
texts.en:
Jose is grateful to Kiva lenders because, thanks to their support, he will be able to make improvements to his home, like repairing walls, painting, repairing windows, etc. This way, he will be able to improve his quality of life. 

Above all, he is a young man with a great desire to move forward. Because of this, he works as a janitor and performs maintenance on machines at a small business in the city where he lives. This is how he earns money to pay for household expenses and work towards his dream, which is to own his own home.

loans.use: to improve his home (repair walls, paint, repair windows, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food products in bulk.

loans.name: Sibonanjani

texts.en:
Sibonanjani is a 30-year-old young woman. She lives in Nkayi District in Zimbabwe. She is a mother of two and a seasoned member of Cama, Camfed’s alumnae network.

She has been successfully running a grocery shop for the past two years. She sells items like sugar, cooking oil, coffee creamers and salt. As a Cama member, she is a volunteer teacher to her community on issues like child abuse, HIV/AIDS and other health issues.

With the requested Kiva loan, she will stock up on a variety of groceries in bulk. This will increase her sales volume and will help her gain more profits. With the profits, she wants to provide for her family and also assist the needy in her community.

loans.use: to purchase more stock

loans.name: Sichelesile

texts.en:
Sichelesile is a 17-year-old mother of one. She lives in Nkayi District, Zimbabwe. In her community she sells clothes like men’s jeans, t-shirts for men and women as well as bags. When she is not working at her business, she comes together with other young women to disseminate health information in her community. 

With the Kiva loan, Sichelesile will improve her business by purchasing more and better quality clothes from wholesalers. This will allow her to purchase the clothes at a lower cost and sell them to the community for a higher profit margin. With increased profits, she wants to expand her business, create employment for her community and remain financially independent. She also plans to further her education by enrolling in a teacher’s college and be a good role model to people in her community.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Sakina is a 34-year-old businesswoman who is married with four children and lives in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe. She is a member of Cama, Camfed’s alumni network and also serves as a Learner Guide at the nearest secondary school, assisting young women with life and study skills. She has been successfully raising broiler chickens for eight months now with assistance from her family members, and every six weeks produces a batch of 50 broiler birds. With the requested Kiva loan she intends to expand her business by increasing batches of birds to 100 every six weeks and thus having an increase in income to improve the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more broiler chicks and the supplies needed to raise them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more broiler chicks and the supplies needed to raise them.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon is a 19-year-old businesswoman and mother of one. She lives in the Nkayi District of Zimbabwe where she is an active member of Cama, Camfed’s alumnae network. In addition to being a Cama District Representative, Sharon volunteers her time as a Learner Guide who delivers life skills sessions to students in schools. 

To support her family, Sharon sells groceries such as cooking oil, soft drinks, sugar, salt and sweets. She will use the Kiva loan to purchase groceries from wholesalers at lower costs and sell them at favorable prices to attract customers. This will increase her sales and profits. With the additional profits she wants to expand into a bigger business, create employment for her community and continue her education.

loans.use: to purchase groceries in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chicks and chick feed in bulk in order to increase her sales.

loans.name: Lovely

texts.en:
Lovely is a 21-year-old young woman who lives in Nkayi District, Zimbabwe, where she runs a business selling clothes and shoes to local residents.

She began the business after receiving training from Cama, Camfed’s alumnae network. The training gave her the confidence and skills necessary to be a successful vendor in the local market.  Lovely also volunteers as a Learner Guide at a local school in her community where she takes students through sessions on well-being and life skills. 

She will use the requested Kiva loan to expand her business through ordering more clothes and shoes of increased quality in order to make her business more competitive. Due to limited capital, Lovely is unable to purchase these items on her own. An increase in profits will enable her to support her siblings’ education since they have no parents. She will also help the needy and the community at large through the creation of employment opportunities.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her business by purchasing more stock and bring in a higher profit.

loans.name: Knowledge

texts.en:
Knowledge is a 20-year-old, single mother with one child, who lives in the Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. She works very hard to be successful in her poultry business and she is excited to see it grow in the future. 

Some of her free time is spent working as a Camfed Learner Guide at schools in her community, helping to improve young people’s well-being. She also runs a small poultry business, selling broiler chickens within her community. 

Knowledge really enjoys managing her business and would love to see it grow. She is seeking a Kiva loan to purchase more broiler chicks as well as the feed and supplies required to raise them. 

Growing her business will help her become more financially independent and ensure that she can provide for herself and her child. She also wants to contribute positively to the needy within her community.

loans.use: to purchase more broiler chicks as well as the feed and supplies required to raise them.

loans.name: Lee Esnath

texts.en:
Lee is married with two children and lives in the Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. As an entrepreneur, Lee runs a business selling poultry to local residents. She takes great pride in her business since it provides quality meat to her community and she is enthusiastic to see it grow with the support of a Kiva loan. 

With the Kiva loan, Lee will buy chicks and chick feed in bulk in order to grow the capacity of her business. With the profits from an increase in sales, Lee hopes to improve her family’s standard of living and assist families who are struggling. Her desire to give back to her community is already present as she is a Camfed Learner Guide who volunteers in schools on a weekly basis and provides support to students by teaching them valuable life skills.

loans.use: To buy chicks and chick feed in bulk in order to grow the capacity of her business.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is an entrepreneur and mother of one from Nkayi District, Zimbabwe. She is a member of Cama, Camfed’s alumnae network, where she is a Learner Guide who teaches students life skills and about their well-being. 

To support herself financially, Florence sells groceries to local community members. She plans to use the Kiva loan to buy more groceries to increase sales, and will rent a shop at her local business area using the additional profits. This will enable her to create employment for her community and provide for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es: Teresa tiene 26 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañero de vida y sus dos hijos de 7 y 4 años de edad. Teresa es una mujer dedica y responsable. Ella trabaja como empleada en la una institución cercana a su localidad. Teresa solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de puertas y ventanas para la vivienda dado que se encuentran deterioradas y desea dar mayor seguridad a su familia.
texts.en:
Teresa is 26 years old and lives in her own home with her husband and their two children, ages 7 and 4. Teresa is a dedicated and responsible woman. She works as an employee at an institution near her home.

Teresa requests this loan from FUSAI to invest in the purchase of doors and windows for her home, since hers are currently deteriorating and she wants to make her home more secure for her family.

loans.use: to purchase doors and windows for her home.

loans.name: Geovany Isaias

texts.es: Geovany tiene 40 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañero de vida y su hija de 8 años y su hijo de 4 años de edad. Geovany se dedica a la venta de granos básicos como frijoles y arroz. De esta forma se gana la vida y lleva el sustento a su hogar. Geovany solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra cemento, arena, grava, tela metálica, y postes de cemento para encementar el piso de la vivienda y para cercar el terreno.
texts.en:
Geovany is 40 years old and lives in his own home with his wife and their 8-year-old daughter and 4-year-old son. Geovany makes a living by selling staple crops like beans and rice. This way, he earns a living and supports his household.

Geovany requests this loan from FUSAI to invest in the purchase of cement, sand, gravel, mesh, and cement posts to cement the floor of his home and to build a fence around his land.

loans.use: to purchase cement, sand, gravel, mesh, and cement posts to cement the floor of his home and to build a fence around his land.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a 31-year-old businesswoman. She is married with two children and lives in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe. She has been rearing broiler chickens for eight months now with the assistance of her husband. Juliet volunteers in her spare time, assisting girls at the nearest secondary school in her community by counseling them as well as cleaning the school premises. 

With the requested Kiva loan, she intends to increase her broiler production by purchasing a batch of 50 broilers per week so that her sales and profit levels can improve. With the additional profits, she intends to pay school fees for her children as well as her siblings.

loans.use: To purchase more broiler chicks and supplies to raise them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock in higher volumes and increase her profitability

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 54-year-old married woman. She has 5 children. She describes herself to be determined.

She operates a market stall where she sells cereals. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of capital.

She will use the 20,000 KES loan to add stock of beans. Her business goal is to own a wholesale stall within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits from the loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to add stock of beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a married man. He has five children. He describes himself as focused. 

He operates a butchery shop where he sells meat. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in an area with potential. He describes his biggest business challenge as insecurity. 

He will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of meat and other items to enable him to open a new branch. His business goal is to own several branches within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be a supplier of meat. This is his second loan with SMEP Micro finance bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of meat and other items to enable him open a new branch.

loans.name: In God Group

texts.en:
This group is called In God Group and it consists of six people who live in Accra-Teshie, Ghana. They applied for a group loan of GHS 5,000 from ID Ghana.

Mary is a hard-working, 52-year-old, married woman who lives with her family. She is the featured borrower of the group. Mary is an educated woman with a secondary school education. 

Mary has had her business selling earrings, perfume, and wigs. She has also provided hairdressing services in a kiosk in her neighborhood for more than 12 years. She started her business with a small amount of capital, thanks to the assistance of her husband, who supported her financially. 

Year by year, her business continues to improve, but most of what she earns in profit goes to the expenses of the family. She has good experience in this business. 

Unfortunately, the income of this business is not enough to provide her family with a better future and she wants to improve it. For this reason, she applied for a loan of GHS 1,500 from ID Ghana in order to purchase more earrings, perfume, wigs, shampoo, and conditioners to sell to her customers and to use some to style her customers' hair.

Mary looks forward to further expanding her business in order to provide her family with a secure future.

The group members will hold each other responsible for the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more earrings, perfume, wigs, shampoo, and conditioners.

loans.name: Samkeliso

texts.en:
Twenty-seven-year-old businesswoman Samkeliso is married with two children and lives in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe. She has been rearing broiler chickens successfully for eight months now with the assistance of her husband. Samkeliso is a member of Cama, Camfed’s alumni network, and volunteers her spare time with the physically challenged in her community by assisting them in fetching water. On top of that, she works as a facilitator, running sessions offering guidance and counseling to students at local schools. 

With the requested Kiva loan, she intends to purchase a batch of 50 broiler chicks every week, thus increasing the production to meet the high demand of customers. With the additional profits, she will be able to meet the financial needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more broiler chicks and the supplies to raise them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her stock, and therefore, make more profit

loans.name: Noliwe

texts.en: Noliwe is a 20-year-old businesswoman living in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe with her grandparents. Noliwe volunteers her spare time facilitating guidance and counseling sessions to young people in her community. Noliwe, along with her grandparents, have been successfully rearing broiler chickens for ten months by producing batches of 25 chickens every six weeks. With the requested Kiva loan she intends to increase the number of chicks she produces so that she can, in turn, receive larger profits. With these additional profits, she intends to purchase an additional plot for rearing more chicks.

loans.use: to purchase more broiler chicks and the supplies to raise them.

loans.name: Acquelline

texts.en:
Acqualine lives in the Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. She is a Camfed Learner Guide working with schools in her community to improve young people’s wellbeing. In addition, she is running a poultry project selling chickens to local residents. 
She loves her business and is seeking a Kiva loan so that she can purchase chicks, chemicals and stock feed in bulk to increase her profit margin. With the profits, she intends to improve her standard of living and help the needy in her community.

loans.use: To purchase chicks, chemicals and stock feed in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.name: Sehllin Liseth

texts.es: Sehllin es una mujer de carácter fuerte, que le gusta trabajar para que a sus hijos no le falte lo necesario en la vida,  labora de tiempo completo en su negocio en donde vende ropa variada, el crédito que solicita es para aumentar su inventario comprando ropa variada, calzado y cosméticos, con el propósito de  mejorar las ventas que son el principal sostén del hogar.
texts.en:
Sehllin is a woman with a strong character who enjoys working so that her children do not lack necessary things in life. She works full time at her business where she sells various types of clothing.

The loan that she is requesting will be used to increase her inventory with various clothing, footwear, and cosmetics so that she can increase her sales, since this is the main way that she supports her household.

loans.use: to purchase various clothing, footwear, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tables and chairs to use in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more lappa.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is married with two children and lives in the Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. As a volunteer Learner Guide for Camfed, Sarah works with students in her community to improve young people’s well-being by teaching them life and study skills. To support her family financially, Sarah runs a poultry project selling broiler chickens. She loves her business and is seeking a Kiva loan so that she can purchase chicks, chemicals and stock feed in bulk to increase her sales. In the future, she intends to improve her standard of living and help the needy people in her community with the profits.

loans.use: to purchase chicks, chemicals and stock feed in bulk to increase her sales.

loans.name: Anonymous
